Hello Colin-

Sorry about the delayed response. I have been traveling a lot=
 lately.

For a long time I thought I was using a larger set of activation =
functions
in HyperNEAT, and wrote that up in some of my publications, but I=
 discovered
recently that there is an obscure line of code in an unrelated =
section of
the code base that actually reduced my function set to the follo=
wing:

Sigmoid
Gaussian
Linear
Sine

So, those are what I have been using i=
n all of my papers. I will update the
online versions of these papers on my=
 website to reflect this fact. Sorry
for any confusion. 

As for other pape=
rs,

I believe that Jason's papers used the following:

    =80    sigmoid
=
    =80    Gaussian
    =80    sine
    =80    linear 

And David's papers =
used these:
    =80    sigmoid
    =80    Gaussian
    =80    sine
    =80 =
   absolute value

However, I also think that Jason once told me that Dave =
only uses nodes with
positive outputs, so his absolute value might actually=
 reduce to a linear.
Is that right David?

I think it would be interesting =
to see comparisons of HyperNEAT with
different activation functions. As Ken=
 said, this area remains mostly
unexplored.  Please let us know if you do a=
ny tests.


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State Unive=
rsity

jclune@...

vation functions. I figure they are:

> Sigmoid

> Abs
> Sine

id and Jef Clune's paper used a whole load more...

> Cosine
> Square

inear

>

re may be other variations, these are just some I spotted just now.
